bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Carlos E. Finlay, January 6, 1942

div1.p: Hench discusses Carlos J. Finlay's contributions to the study of yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Carlos E. Finlay, January 6, 1942
div1.opener:
January 6, 1942
Dr. C. E. Finlay
Vedado, Habana
Cuba
My dear Doctor Finlay:
div1.p:
I appreciate greatly your very nice Christmas card and especially
your letter of December 22.

I am delighted to have you make any comments on my papers that you
see fit to make. You say that you disagree with my repeated statement that
your father did not produce a single case of experimental yellow fever. I
think if you will re-read my paper carefully you will see in the last para-
graph of the first column on page 2 that I carefully worded the following
sentence: “But nobody believed him simply because, although he had inoculated
over 100 volunteers with mosquitoes, he hadn't produced a single case of the
disease which other physicians regarded as unquestionably induced or experimental
rather than probably spontaneous.” Please note that I have carefully worded this
“which other physicians regarded”. I think that is the true statement of affairs
and does not enter into the controversy as to whether they were actually cases of
yellow fever or not. That controversy did not belong in this particular paper
that I wrote. It belongs to my larger study which I hope to publish in due time
and I can assure you I am trying to investigate every angle of the claims made
for your father. There seems little doubt but that a number of his patients did
develop yellow fever apparently not within the time limits set by the board.
I am getting in touch with a number of the modern yellow fever experts such
as Dr. Wilbur Sawyer and others and before publishing my final work will certainly
re-investigate current ideas on the time limit of incubation period, etc. I am
quite prepared to revise my opinions regarding this. But please let me assure you,
Dr. Finlay, that I am utterly and completely convinced of the tremendous contribu-
tion which your father made. Regardless of whether he was able to prove his theory
with complete success or not, his brilliant conception and the wonderful tenacity
which which he developed his ideas and kept at his theory are deserving of only
the highest praise. Without him and his work the conquest of yellow fever might
not yet have been accomplished. I am sure that you will be satisfied with what
I finally write and I intend to submit my preliminary manuscripts to you and others
in Cuba for your critical appraisal. Let me assure you also that I have the greatest
and most sincere admiration for your father and it is my hope that I can reintro-
duce him in fuller glory to the American public and medical profession.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
